name: crataegus-collina
country-or-region-of-origin: Eastern Canada south to Georgia, west to the Mississippi.
wildlife-value: Important nectar flower for insects; food plant of many moths including the eggar moth; haws provide winter fruit for songbirds.  This plant also provides nectar for pollinators.  It is a larval host plant for Gray Hairstreak (Strymon melinus), Red-spotted Purple (Limenitis arthemis astyanax), and Viceroy (Limenitis archippus). Red-spotted Purple and Viceroy rarely use this host plant in North Carolina. Good nesting habitat with thorns providing protection from predators.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Small orange to red pome with 3 to 5 pyrenes that resemble the “stones” in related plums, peaches, etc.  Sometimes called the ‘haw’.
flower-description: The numerous flowers are in corymbs, pubescent to nearly glabrous and 0.5 to 0.8 inches wide, with 5 petals. The flowers are white, with 2-5 styles and 20 pink or yellow stamens.  Blooms in April-May.
leaf-description: Spirally arranged on long stalks. Pubescent, rhombic-obovate in shape. Apex is blunt or rounded and base is tapering.  Lobes 0-2 per side above the middle, margins serrate in distal ¾ of lobes. Undersides paler.  Two to four inches long and 0.8 to 2 inches wide.
bark-description: Smooth and gray bark, fissuring with age.
stem-description: Bark is thin and gray. Twigs are brown to gray, hairy when young, with many short and stout thorns or spines up to 2.5 inches. The bark of older stems tends to break up into narrow scales.
uses: The leaves, berries, and flowers are used in medicines and herbals for cardiovascular health. The wood is strong, tough, heavy, and hard, but has little commercial value.
